subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Milligan poems
msgSnippet: ... In fact, British pronunciations are rapidly moving toward eat for final unstressed -y and its spelling variants.  QS reflects an earlier version of
messageBody:
pgabhart scripsit:

> I haven't taken time to look, but I
> believe the QS manual has an example of the word "pity" written with a
> half-letter "tea" folled by "it." This wouldn't work with the American
> pronunciation as we would use "eat" at the end, but it works fine with
> the British pronunciation so I am not sure why you dismissed that
> possibility.

In fact, British pronunciations are rapidly moving toward "eat" for final
unstressed "-y" and its spelling variants. QS reflects an earlier version
of Received Pronunciation in many of its choices -- another reason why
standardized orthography is important.

> Regarding the use of abbreviations: I have no idea what "YMMV" is
> supposed to mean,

"Your mileage may vary". See
http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/your_mileage_may_vary .

--
Income tax, if I may be pardoned for saying so, John Cowan
is a tax on income. --Lord Macnaghten (1901) cowan@...
